content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice work, just in time to make it in 5 minutes but it's funny

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

I really like how you formatted the goal section. I could easily see what I needed to do without even knowing what Dofus is. I just follow the steps in the rules section. Well done!

Some suggestions:
* Format the variable O in the rules section as a variable. There are two occurences.
* Clarify that "... empty cells will be represented by . (a dot) ...". As it is now, it's a bit hard to see what character is used.
* Add in the output section that the damage multiplier will be a number with two decimals. I know it's already specified in the task section, but I think it should be in both.
* Very optional: the section separators (the dashed lines) are not equal in length.

Feel free to bump this to get an approval after looking at the suggestions (and either implementing them or telling me why you won't :) ).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As someone completely unfamiliar with Dofus, I believe this problem is perfectly comprehensible and of reasonable difficulty.
It would make a good Clash of Code, not the easiest one for sure but largely doable for the more experienced players.
Given the space constraints, more naive approaches would work out too, so it is not even algorithmically complex to solve.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The problem is way too complex for a Clash of code.

As someone completely unfamiliar with "MMORPG Dofus" this makes no sense to me.
Including, but not limited to, what is "the Arena" ??

Maybe everyone else knows, and "gets it" and I'm just an outlier, but that is at least one person's perspective.  If this came up as a CoC for me, I would just exit out.
Bon, jeux de tests clairs, trop long selon moi pour un clash mais super pour un puzzle :)
The problem has been greatly simplified (no equidistance) and the former problem is now a puzzle

It looks like more suitable to be a puzzle than a clash.

Also, please remember to format the variables in the Constraints section.
My brain melts reading your solution but telling by it and the statement it probably is too hard or too long for a clash of code

I am thinking about doing this as a puzzle.
And as a clash, this but without any equidistance cases.

The preamble ("context") introduces objects which are defined afterwards, for example "The arena will be a square matrix" . What else did you not understand? I can reword the statement to make it clearer for everyone.
It's not.
Done

100%
The statement itself is over 200 words! It takes at least 4-5 minutes to just understand the problem, then you have to solve it. It's solvable in 15 minutes, but no one wants to have to read that much before they can start solving a clash.

I just got this as a "Shortest" mode clash, and everyone got 0%. My computer unfortunately crashed, so I lost 8 minutes of play-time, but others clearly struggled even with 15 minutes.
It's solvable, but it would be a lot better if it was re-phrased to remove all the context and just solve the problem of visiting all the different nodes in order and outputting the distance of the total route (no multiplier).

I mean, it's possible that I just don't have a part of the brain necessary to understand this, because other comments indicate others understand it

But when you ask me " What else did you not understand?"
I don't understand any of it, even after reading it 10 more times.

A spell is cast thru a number in a square matrix (called an arena)??  What on earth could that possibly mean.  It just sounds like words run together.

Okay, after reading it 5 more times, and looking at the examples, I think I get it now, but this is a whole new concept and I would never get it within a 15 minute clash.

You may want to just see me as an outlier, and just continue on.

(I hope my feedback was somewhat helpful.)

If I'm understanding it now, here is a suggestion for re-wording:

In the MMORPG Dofus, players play on a field called the Arena.
This is represented by a rectangle of dots.

Within the Arena, players can create Portals.  Each Portal is represented by a numbers such as 1, 2, 3, etc

A player can "cast a spell thru a Portal".  This means that an action started in one Portal continues on thru all the other Portals, in a manner that depends on the specifics of that "spell"

That was the background that I didn't understand.

You don't have to pay much attention to the "context" part, that's why it's called like that, it's just some lore. A portal is represented by a number, as you can see in the test cases, because the portals are numbered, portal number 1 , portal number 2 etc... so it's just a special location (special location number 1, special location number 2 etc...) on the map/arena/matrix. And then from onward, given the special location from which you will start you just have to construct the route in which the next waypoint is the closest special location from you among all the special locations that you have not yet visited, and to move to that waypoint , and to do that until every special location has been visited, and you have to return the list of these waypoints, in order, and a number computed from the total distance of that route that you constructed. 

For example in test 3. You start from the special location number 1 (because 8 1 is given: map is 8*8 locations and the special location from which you start is numbered "1") , so you need to know what special location is closest to special location number 1 and it will be special location number 3 which is 4 cells away in manhattan distance and then the closest special location to special location number 3 which has not yet been visited will be special location number  2 which is 3 cells away in manhattan distance, and then there is only one special location that has not yet been visited which is special location number 4 so that will be the last waypoint of the route and it is 4 cells away in manhattan distance from our current location which was special location number 2. So the route goes "1 3 2 4" and the total distance of that route is 4 (going from special location number 1 to special location number 3) + 3 (going from special location number 3 to special location number 2) + 4  (going from special location number 2 to special location number 4) = 11 and if you inject 11 in the given formula the number to return is 1.25+11*0.02= 1.47
So you need to return the route: "1 3 2 4" and one line below, the number "1.47" .

I just think you are assuming that EVERYONE knows what "cast a spell" means and how "portals" are related to "arena".

Admittedly I have never heard of "MMORPG Dofus" and maybe everyone else on CG has, and you just want to make that assumption. 

I am just pointing out that you are assuming knowledge/background that people might not have.

The thing is, one doesn't have to know what those words specifically mean, one can just abstract them and still solve the problem, well at least I thought so.
Maybe my english is just bad and it is "cast a spell on" and not "cast a spell through", so I changed that to be more accurate.
